choices.text: Metastasis to breast from another primary site

questions.text: Identify the image. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fibroadenoma

 

On ultrasound, fibroadenomas typically appear as well-defined, homogeneous, hypoechoic (dark) masses with smooth margins. They may sometimes exhibit a 'halo' sign, which is a thin, echogenic rim surrounding the lesion. The mass in the image shows these characteristic features, making fibroadenoma a likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Breast Cyst: Cysts are fluid-filled sacs within the breast. On ultrasound, they appear as anechoic (completely black) round or oval structures with well-defined edges and posterior acoustic enhancement (increased brightness behind the cyst due to lack of absorption of ultrasound waves by the fluid). The lesion in the image does not show these typical features of a cyst.

 

Option C. Breast Carcinoma: Breast cancers can appear in various forms on ultrasound, but they typically present as irregular, microlobulated, or spiculated masses with heterogenous echotexture and may show shadowing due to their density. The margins are often ill-defined, which is not consistent with the well-defined borders seen in the image.

 

Option D. Metastasis to Breast from Another Primary Site: Metastases to the breast are rare and usually present as multiple round masses that can mimic benign lesions. However, they are not common and typically have a background of known primary malignancy elsewhere, which isn't indicated here.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Fibroadenoma appearance on USG is as a ‘Halo’ sign.

questions.text: A dead body is brought for evaluation. On post-mortem examination, a ligature that was completely encircling the neck, horizontal, and below the level of the thyroid was seen. There was no dribbling of saliva. What is the cause of death? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ligature strangulation  

 

The presence of a ligature mark that completely encircles the neck, is horizontal, and located below the level of the thyroid cartilage is indicative of ligature strangulation. This type of mark differentiates it from other forms of neck compression injuries.

 

Additional Clues:

 

  • Dribbling of Saliva: The absence of dribbling of saliva suggests that the cause of death is not hanging. Dribbling of saliva is the surest sign of antemortem hanging.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Throttling: Throttling involves manual strangulation using hands, not a ligature. It would show different injury patterns on the neck.

 

Option C. Gagging: Gagging involves the insertion of a foreign object into the mouth to prevent breathing, which would show different internal and external signs.

 

Option D. Hanging: Hanging would typically show a ligature mark that is oblique and above the level of the thyroid cartilage, along with signs such as dribbling of saliva.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child is presenting with palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, and pain in the knee joint resulting from arthritis. Urine examination showed hematuria and proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henoch-Schonlein purpura

 

The combination of palpable blanching purpura, abdominal pain, joint pain resulting from arthritis, and urinary findings of hematuria and proteinuria is characteristic of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

The clinical presentation and the investigations are suggestive of Henoch-Schonlein purpura.

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a systemic immune disorder characterized by a purpuric rash, abdominal pain, polyarthralgia, and renal abnormalities. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years.

 

The patient may present with the following clinical features:

 

  • Skin lesions- These typically involve the extensor surfaces of the arms and legs, as well as the buttocks.
  • Pain, vomiting, and intestinal bleeding are examples of abdominal manifestations.
  • Renal manifestations include hematuria, nephritic syndrome, and nephrotic syndrome. Adults have more severe renal manifestations. Some patients develop a rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immune thrombocytopenic purpura: typically presents with isolated thrombocytopenia and mucocutaneous bleeding, without joint pain or abdominal pain.

 

Option B. Dengue fever: Dengue fever is a viral illness that typically presents with fever, headache, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, and rash.

 

Option C. Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome is a rare systemic autoimmune disease that typically presents with asthma, eosinophilia, and systemic vasculitis, often involving multiple organs. While arthritis may be seen in Churg-Strauss syndrome, palpable purpura is uncommon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schonlein purpura is characterized by the presence of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, arthritis, and renal involvement, typically manifesting as hematuria and proteinuria. It is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly affecting children and is distinguished by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in affected tissues.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Bandage and padding of the eye

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who had undergone an uneventful cataract surgery with intraocular lens implantation, presents with complaints of pain and visual disturbance in the operated eye, 36 hours post operatively. His eye is as shown below. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Intravitreal antibiotics

 

The given image shows an inflamed eye with the presence hypopyon, which along with the history of a recent cataract surgery is suggestive of endophthalmitis.

 

Endophthalmitis is an inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball associated with exudate pouring in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

 

Modes of infection:

 

  1. Exogenous: following perforating injuries, perforation of infected corneal ulcers, or postoperative infections.
  2. Endogenous or metastatic endophthalmitis: occurs rarely through the bloodstream from some infected focus.
  3. Secondary infections from surrounding structures: rare.
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: most frequent pathogens are gram-positive cocci, such as staphylococcus epidermidis and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Fungal endophthalmitis: comparatively rare, caused by aspergillus, fusarium, candida, etc.
  • Cardinal features: Pain, lid swelling, and decreased vision. Inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and hypopyon may also occur.
  • Treatment:
    • Intraocular fluid from anterior chamber or vitreous biopsy is sent for gram staining, KOH mount and culture.
    • Intravitreal injection of antibiotics is the primary therapy. Patient needs to be monitored daily to assess for resolution of clinical symptoms and repeat intravitreal antibiotic injections may be given as required.
    • Topical broadspectrum antibiotics, cycloplegics are also given simultaneously.
    • Oral steroids may be given.
    • Systemic antibiotics have no role in the management of endophthalmitis..

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intravenous steroids: Not the primary treatment for endophthalmitis. Steroids may be used to reduce inflammation but not as the main intervention.

 

Option B. Intravenous antibiotics: Systemic antibiotics have limited effectiveness due to poor penetration into the eye.

 

Option C. Bandage and padding of the eye: Provides no therapeutic benefit for endophthalmitis and delays appropriate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravitreal antibiotics are the primary treatment for endophthalmitis, a severe postoperative complication characterized by inflammation and hypopyon. Early and aggressive treatment is crucial to prevent vision loss.

choices.text: Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex
Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex
Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person
Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

questions.text: Frotteurism is defined as: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sexual gratification by rubbing his private parts against another person

 

Frotteurism involves the act of touching or rubbing one's genitals against another non-consenting individual in a sexual manner, to attain sexual gratification.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Eonism (also known as Transvestism)
  • Description: Involves obtaining sexual pleasure or emotional satisfaction by wearing clothes traditionally associated with the opposite sex.

 

Option B. Desire to seek surgery to become a member of opposite sex

 

  • Term: Transsexualism
  • Description: Involves a strong desire to undergo surgery to change one's biological sex to align with one's gender identity.

 

Option D. Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger

 

  • Term: Exhibitionism
  • Description: Involves exposing one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger for sexual gratification. This behavior is typically intended to shock or arouse the observer.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Act of rubbing one's genitals against another person without their consent to achieve sexual arousal or gratification - Frotteurism
  • Obtaining sexual pleasure by wearing clothes of opposite sex – Eonism
  • Desire to seek surgery to become member of opposite sex - Transsexualism
  • Exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger- Exhibitionism

choices.text: A case of superfetation
One infant is atavistic
A case of superfecundation
One infant is suppositious

questions.text: A married woman gives birth to twins. The husband doubts he is the father and gets a paternity test done. The test shows that he is the father of one infant but not the other. This is? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A case of superfecundation

 

Explanation:

 

Superfecundation:

 

  • This refers to the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different acts of intercourse, potentially involving different partners.
  • This scenario explains how twins can have different fathers, as one ovum could be fertilized by sperm from the husband, and the other by sperm from another man.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfetation: This refers to fertilization of two ova from different menstrual cycles. It is an extremely rare phenomenon and has never been documented in humans, though it is known to occur in some animals.

 

Option B. One infant is atavistic: Atavism refers to the appearance of characteristics found in distant ancestors but not observed in recent generations. It does not apply to paternity.

 

Option D. One infant is suppositious: Suppositious refers to something that is fraudulently substituted. This term does not explain the situation of having different fathers for twins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Superfecundation is the fertilization of two ova in the same menstrual cycle by sperm from different partners, explaining how twins can have different fathers.

 

Ref: Page no 2188, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

questions.text: Which condition is suggested by a painful red eye with a small and irregular pupil? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Iritis/Iridocyclitis

 

Iritis/iridocyclitis classically presents with a painful red eye with circumcorneal congestion. The key diagnostic sign is the constricted and irregular pupil, which results from inflammation of the iris causing sphincter spasm and the formation of posterior synechiae. This pattern of symptoms forms a distinctive clinical picture that helps differentiate anterior uveitis from other causes of red eye.

 

Visual Support: In acute iritis, you would observe:

 

  • Pain localized to the eye
  • Circumcorneal redness (ciliary flush)
  • Constricted, irregular pupil
  • Cells in the anterior chamber
  • Keratic precipitates on the cornea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Conjunctivitis: While conjunctivitis causes redness, it presents with foreign body sensation and itching rather than localized pain. The pupil remains normal in size and shape, unlike the constricted irregular pupil seen in iritis. The congestion is conjunctival rather than circumcorneal.

 

Option B. Corneal Ulcer: Though corneal ulcers present with pain and redness, the pupil is typically constricted but not irregular. The primary features are corneal ulceration/suppuration, which are not mentioned in the question scenario.

 

Option D. Acute Glaucoma: Acute glaucoma presents with a fixed, mid-dilated pupil (not constricted and irregular). It typically causes severe pain radiating beyond the eye, often with headache, nausea and vomiting, and marked elevation of intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

A constricted, irregular pupil with circumcorneal redness and localized eye pain is the classic presentation of anterior uveitis (iritis/iridocyclitis) and should prompt immediate ophthalmologic evaluation to prevent complications like posterior synechiae and secondary glaucoma.

questions.text: Which intradermal test is employed for diagnosing Bartonella? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Foshay Test

 

Explanation:

The Foshay test is the specific intradermal skin test used to diagnose Bartonella henselae infections (cat-scratch disease). This skin test produces a positive reaction in patients with cat-scratch disease, providing a useful diagnostic tool in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphogranuloma Venereum Test - This is incorrect because the LGV test (Frei test) is used specifically for diagnosing Lymphogranuloma Venereum caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1-L3, not Bartonella infections.

 

Option C. Leishmania Test - This is incorrect because the Leishmania skin test (Montenegro test) is used to diagnose Leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania species, not Bartonella infections.

 

Option D. Schistosomiasis Test - This is incorrect because intradermal tests for Schistosomiasis detect a different pathogen entirely and are not relevant for Bartonella diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bartonella infections (cat-scratch disease) are diagnosed using the Foshay test, which is a specific intradermal skin test that helps identify this infection in immunocompetent individuals.

questions.text: Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inflammation without purulent discharge

 

MULTIFOCAL NON-SUPPURATIVE OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Focal sterile inflammatory disease with prolonged, self-limiting and recurring episodes.
  • It is an auto-inflammatory disorder that causes bone pain due to inflammation in the bones not caused by infection. 
  • It has been associated with SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, palmo-plantar Hyperostosis and Osteitis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Tenderness in affected area
    • Some patients may develop arthritis
    • Fatigue
    • Chronic pain affecting quality of life
    • Delayed growth in some children
    • Night bone pain
    • Regional palpable swelling over bones with little overlying soft tissue
       
  • Despite the local and systemic signs of inflammation, there is no purulent discharge and microbes are seldom isolated. This is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Mildly elevated CRP and ESR
    • Positive ANA and HLA-B27
    • Elevated serum cytokines
    • Mildly elevated serum TNF-alpha and IL-6
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray shows lytic bone lesions, sclerosis and hyperostosis.
    • MRI is the investigation of choice
    • Whole body MRI provides information about lesion distribution, soft tissue involvement, and/or possible involvement of additional organs
    • Bone biopsy reveals dense infiltrates of immune cells, bone lysis, fibrosis, and/or normal bone.
       
  • Treatment:
    • NSAIDs are first-line agents for quick symptomatic relief and control inflammation
    • Corticosteroids, DMARDs, anti-TNF agents, and bisphosphonates are effective in some patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by inflammation without any purulent discharge.

questions.text: The Indirect Coomb's test detects: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Antibodies in the serum

 

Explanation:
 

The Indirect Coombs test (also called indirect antiglobulin test) detects antibodies present in the patient's serum that may bind to donor erythrocytes. This test involves obtaining the recipient's serum, adding donor blood samples, and looking for antibody-antigen complexes. When anti-human immunoglobulins (Coombs reagent) are added to the solution, agglutination occurs if human antibodies have attached to the red blood cells, indicating a positive test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibodies attached to the RBC surface: This describes what the Direct Coombs test detects. The Direct test examines antibodies already bound to the patient's own RBCs.

 

Option C. Antigens attached to the RBC surface: The test detects antibodies, not antigens. While antigens on RBCs are what the antibodies bind to, the test specifically identifies the antibodies.

 

Option D. Antigens in the serum: Antigens are typically cell-surface molecules, not free-floating in serum. The test specifically identifies antibodies in serum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Indirect Coombs test is a critical pretransfusion screening test that detects antibodies in a recipient's serum that could react with donor RBCs, helping prevent potentially fatal hemolytic transfusion reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the standard normal distribution curve is true? [NEET PG 2017]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mean = Median

 

  • The standard normal distribution curve, also known as the Gaussian distribution, is a perfectly symmetrical, bell-shaped curve.
  • This symmetry means that the mean, median, and mode of the distribution are equal and all lie at the center of the curve. This characteristic implies that for a standard normal distribution, the mean equals the median, and both are equal to the mode.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mean = 2 Median: Incorrect because, in a standard normal distribution, the mean is equal to the median, not twice the median.

 

Option C. Median = Variance: Incorrect because the median is a measure of central tendency, while the variance is a measure of dispersion; they are not equal.

 

Option D. Standard Deviation = Variance: Incorrect as the standard deviation is the square root of the variance. For a standard normal distribution, the variance is 1, and the standard deviation is also 1, but they are not equal in general mathematical terms.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a standard normal distribution, the mean, median, and mode are equal and coincide at the center of the distribution.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman with BMI 32, was on atypical antipsychotic drugs. She presented with a complaint of weight gain. Which of the following drugs is least commonly associated with weight gain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ziprasidone

 

Atypical antipsychotics are known to vary in their propensity to cause weight gain. Among the options given, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain.

 

Clozapine and olanzapine are the antipsychotics most commonly associated with significant weight gain, whereas ziprasidone and aripiprazole are associated with minimal to no weight gain.

 

Thus, in the case of a patient concerned about weight gain, ziprasidone would be the preferable choice.

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Risperidone: This drug is known to cause moderate weight gain in patients.

 

Option B. Quetiapine: This drug is also associated with weight gain, although not as much as clozapine or olanzapine.

 

Option D. Chlorpromazine: This is a typical antipsychotic and is known to cause significant weight gain.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among antipsychotic medications, ziprasidone is least commonly associated with weight gain, making it a better option for patients concerned about this side effect.

questions.text: Accidental death occurred in a man 3 days after the accident. During the postmortem examination, bleeding was observed in the head that was not washed away by water. This can be due to: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subarachnoid bleeding

 

In postmortem examinations, different types of intracranial hemorrhages can be observed. Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is characterized by bleeding that occurs between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater. This type of bleeding is protected by the arachnoid mater, making it resistant to being washed away by water during an autopsy. The presence of persistent bleeding after washing indicates that it is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

 

Note – EDH Vs SDH Vs SAH

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epidural bleeding: Epidural hemorrhage (EDH) occurs between the dura mater and the skull. It is typically easy to identify and does not remain after washing.

 

Option C. SDH: Subdural hemorrhage (SDH) occurs between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater. This type of bleeding usually washes away with water during an autopsy.

 

Option D. Intraparenchymal bleeding: Intraparenchymal bleeding occurs within the brain tissue itself. While it may not wash away completely, the described scenario specifically matches the characteristics of subarachnoid bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is identified by the persistence of bleeding in the head that is not washed away by water during an autopsy, due to its protection by the arachnoid mater

questions.text: A patient is presenting with a staggering gait and nystagmus (Rhomberg sign +ve) after a road traffic accident. Which lobe of cerebellum is affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Flocculonodular

 

The symptoms described—staggering gait, nystagmus, and a positive Rhomberg sign—are indicative of damage to the cerebellum, specifically the flocculonodular lobe. The flocculonodular lobe is responsible for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex, which is crucial for stabilizing vision during head movements. The presence of nystagmus (involuntary eye movements) suggests a disturbance in the vestibulo-ocular reflex, pointing towards a lesion in the flocculonodular lobe. This part of the cerebellum is particularly involved in coordinating the balance and equilibrium of the body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dentate: The dentate nucleus is involved in the planning and execution of fine motor movements rather than the maintenance of balance and posture.

 

Option C. Anterior lobe: The anterior lobe of the cerebellum is primarily associated with coordinating limb movements and maintaining muscle tone.

 

Option D. Vermis: The vermis is responsible for controlling the body's midline movements, such as the trunk and head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flocculonodular lobe of the cerebellum is crucial for maintaining balance, posture, and controlling the vestibulo-ocular reflex. Damage to this area can lead to symptoms such as a staggering gait, nystagmus, and balance issues, as seen in the case of cerebellar ataxia following trauma.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not use antibody marking? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hemagglutination Test

 

The Hemagglutination Test does not involve antibody marking. This test is used primarily to detect the agglutination of red blood cells (RBCs) by substances such as viruses or anti-blood group antibodies. The principle behind hemagglutination involves the ability of certain entities like viruses to bind directly to receptors on the surfaces of RBCs, causing them to clump together without the need for an antibody to be present as a marker.

 

It is routinely performed to type red blood cells in ABO blood-typing.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay): Uses antibodies that are tagged with an enzyme to detect the presence of antigens or other antibodies in a sample through a colorimetric change.

 

Option B. Radioimmunoassay: Involves antibodies or antigens labeled with a radioactive isotope to measure the concentration of substances in the blood.

 

Option C. Immunofluorescence: Utilizes antibodies labeled with fluorescent dyes to detect specific antigens in tissues or cells under a fluorescence microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The hemagglutination test is unique in its use of direct interactions between particles (like viruses) and red blood cells to demonstrate binding and agglutination, distinguishing it from other tests that rely on labeled antibodies to indicate the presence of specific antigens or antibodies. This method is particularly useful in blood typing and viral detection.

questions.text: A neonate was brought with complaints of poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, and cataract. Urine Benedict’s test was positive, while urine glucose was negative. The enzyme defective in this case is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The symptoms described—poor feeding, vomiting, acidosis, cataract, and a positive Benedict’s test with negative urine glucose—are characteristic of classical galactosemia, a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase. This enzyme is crucial in the metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk and dairy products. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in tissues, leading to toxic effects including liver damage, cataract formation (oil drop cataract), and intellectual disability due to energy deficiency in the brain.

 

The positive Benedict’s test indicates the presence of a reducing sugar, which in this case is galactose, not glucose, explaining the negative glucose test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fructokinase: This enzyme is involved in fructose metabolism, specifically converting fructose to fructose-1-phosphate. Its deficiency leads to essential fructosuria, a benign and asymptomatic condition that does not cause the symptoms observed in this case.

 

Option B. Sucrase: Sucrase breaks down sucrose into glucose and fructose. Sucrase deficiency primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms like bloating, gas, and diarrhea after consuming sucrose (common in sugarcane juice). It is unrelated to the clinical presentation described.

 

Option D. Lactase: Lactase is responsible for the digestion of lactose into glucose and galactose. Its deficiency causes lactose intolerance, characterized by diarrhea, gas, and abdominal pain after consuming dairy, but does not lead to acidosis or cataract formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classical galactosemia is caused by a deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to the accumulation of galactose and its metabolites, resulting in serious clinical symptoms including cataracts and liver damage.

questions.text: Propofol infusion syndrome is associated with all of the following except? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypokalemia

 

Propofol infusion syndrome (PRIS) is characterized by hyperkalemia rather than hypokalemia. This severe and potentially fatal complication occurs when propofol infusion is continued for more than 48 hours at high doses (>4 mg/kg/hr). PRIS develops due to impaired free fatty acid metabolism caused by propofol. The syndrome manifests with significant metabolic acidosis (typically lactic acidosis), hyperkalemia, rhabdomyolysis, and acute cardiac dysfunction, which can progress to cardiovascular collapse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic Acidosis: This is a hallmark feature of PRIS. Severe lactic acidosis develops as cellular metabolism becomes impaired, particularly affecting mitochondrial function. The acidosis is a direct result of the metabolic derangements that occur with prolonged high-dose propofol administration.

 

Option B. Rhabdomyolysis: Muscle breakdown is a classic component of PRIS. The syndrome causes skeletal myopathy leading to rhabdomyolysis with elevated creatine kinase levels. This further contributes to the metabolic derangements and can lead to renal failure.

 

Option C. Cardiac Dysfunction: PRIS is associated with acute cardiac failure and cardiomyopathy. The cardiac manifestations include arrhythmias, bradycardia, and Brugada-like ECG patterns. These cardiac effects contribute significantly to the high mortality associated with the syndrome.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Propofol infusion syndrome is a potentially fatal complication characterized by metabolic acidosis, rhabdomyolysis, cardiac dysfunction, and hyperkalemia (not hypokalemia) - making it particularly dangerous in children and requiring close monitoring when prolonged propofol infusions are necessary.

questions.text: What does phase III represent in the below image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alveolar plateau

 

The image represents a capnography waveform, which displays the concentration of carbon dioxide (CO2) in exhaled air. Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the period during exhalation where CO2 levels plateau as alveolar gas is exhaled. This phase reflects the CO2 concentration from the alveoli, which is relatively stable until the end of expiration. The end of phase III corresponds to the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), a key measurement in monitoring ventilation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phase III of the capnography waveform, also known as the alveolar plateau, represents the exhalation of alveolar gas and is used to determine the end-tidal CO2 level.

choices.text: It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration
It shows the phenomenon of redistribution
It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding thiopentone except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It has a short duration of action due to rapid renal excretion

 

Explanation: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution, not rapid renal excretion. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly crosses the blood-brain barrier and enters the brain, causing quick onset of anesthesia. However, it then redistributes to other tissues (muscle and fat), leading to a rapid decrease in brain concentration and therefore a short duration of action. The drug remains in the body but is no longer in sufficient concentration in the brain to maintain anesthetic effects.

 

Other Options:


Option A. It is highly lipid-soluble drug : Correct. Thiopentone is highly lipid-soluble, which enables it to rapidly cross the blood-brain barrier.

 

Option B. It is quickly concentrated in the brain after IV administration : Correct. Due to its high lipid solubility, it rapidly enters the brain within seconds of IV administration.

 

Option C. It shows the phenomenon of redistribution : Correct. After initial brain concentration, thiopentone redistributes to other tissues, particularly muscle and fat.

 

Educational Objective: 


Thiopentone's short duration of action is due to redistribution to other tissues, not rapid renal excretion.

 

THIOPENTONE

 

  • T - Thiobarbiturates 
  • H - Hyperthyroidism 
  • I - Inadvertent intra-arterial injection causes vasospasm (treatment - flush with NS, heparin, lignocaine) 
  • O - pH 10.5 (alkaline) 
  • P - pH 
  • Porphyrias (C/I) 
  • Prolongation of QT interval 
  • E - Epilepsy
  • N - Neuroanesthesia (DOC) 
  • T - Termination of action- redistribution

questions.text: An acute encephalitis outbreak has occurred within the community, prompting the initiation of a vaccination campaign. Which of the following is true about the vaccine given in this condition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Killed and intramuscular

 

Explanation:

 

The question is referring to Japanese Encephalitis (JE) outbreaks, which are not uncommon in India and parts of Southeast Asia. During such outbreaks, emergency vaccination campaigns are often undertaken to control the spread of disease.

 

The most commonly used vaccine in these public health campaigns in India earlier used to be Live JE SA 14-14-2 vaccine (subcutaneous). But nowadays, the inactivated (killed) Vero cell–derived JE vaccine - JENVAC is used intramuscularly.

 

Hence, the correct response based on updated national guidelines is:

 

Killed and intramuscular.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B) Live and subcutaneous:

While the SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live, attenuated vaccine given subcutaneously, recent protocols for outbreak settings increasingly prefer killed vaccines like JENVAC, especially in adult populations and for mass campaigns due to ease of storage and safety. Live vaccine SA -14-14-2 is quite good during outbreaks too. But JENVAC has an edge over SA 14-14-2 because of the higher immunity levels it creates with a single dose. Hence, although previously correct, SA 14-14-2 is no longer the preferred or updated answer.

 

Option C) Live and intramuscular:

Live vaccines (like SA 14-14-2) are given subcutaneously. IM route is not used for Live JE SA 14-14-2 routinely.

 

Option D) Killed and subcutaneous:

Killed JE vaccines (like JENVAC or IXIARO) are administered intramuscularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of a Japanese Encephalitis outbreak, the vaccine currently recommended and used in mass immunization campaigns in India is a killed (inactivated) vaccine administered via the intramuscular route, such as JENVAC. While older guidelines or some regions may have used the live attenuated SA 14-14-2 vaccine given subcutaneously, updated practices now favor the inactivated IM vaccine due to its broader safety profile and compatibility with adult vaccination. Always refer to the most recent national immunization guidelines when answering such public health–related MCQs.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines

 

  • The white fingers suggest the diagnosis of Raynaud's syndrome, which is commonly seen in individuals exposed to vibrating tools like drills and machines.
  •  Raynaud phenomenon is characterized by decreased blood flow to the skin due to arteriolar vasospasm in response to cold or stress.
  • This condition leads to color changes in the skin, transitioning from white (ischemia) to blue (hypoxia) to red (reperfusion).

 

Raynaud's Syndrome:

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arteriolar vasospasm causes decreased blood flow.
  • Triggers: Cold or stress.
  • Symptoms: Color changes in the fingers, pain, and numbness.
  • Risk Factors: Chronic use of vibrating tools (e.g., drills, jackhammers).
  • Types:
    • Primary (Idiopathic): No associated medical condition.
    • Secondary: Associated with connective tissue diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), CREST syndrome (a form of systemic sclerosis), or mixed connective tissue disease. Digital ulceration (critical ischemia) is seen in secondary Raynaud's syndrome.
  • Treatment: Calcium channel blockers (e.g., nifedipine) to reduce the frequency and severity of vasospastic episodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water: Candidal infections usually cause red, itchy, and swollen skin, often with pustules and a whitish coating. They do not present as white, ischemic fingers typical of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Option B. Exposure to thinners and paints: While exposure to thinners and paints can cause dermatitis and other skin conditions, they do not typically result in the vasospastic changes seen in Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

Option C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete: Continuous exposure to cement and concrete can cause contact dermatitis and other dermatological issues but is not associated with the vasospasm and color changes characteristic of Raynaud's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Raynaud's syndrome is characterized by episodic vasospastic attacks in response to cold or stress, leading to color changes in the fingers.
  •  Chronic exposure to vibrating tools, such as drills and machines, is a common occupational risk factor for developing this condition.
  • Treatment includes the use of calcium channel blockers to manage symptoms.

choices.text: Carcinoid tumor of the ovary
Theca cell tumor

questions.text: Which of the following is a virilizing ovarian tumor? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arrhenoblastoma

 

Arrhenoblastoma, also known as Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor, is a virilizing ovarian tumor that can produce androgens leading to masculinization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brenner tumor: Brenner tumors are epithelial ovarian cancer

 

Option C. Carcinoid tumor of the ovary: Carcinoid tumors is a germ cell tumor, primarily produce serotonin and do not typically cause virilization.

 

Option D. Theca cell tumor: Theca cell tumors are sex xord tumours and can produce estrogen, not androgens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arrhenoblastoma is a virilizing ovarian tumor known for its androgen production, often leading to masculinizing symptoms in females.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is having tapping movements and lack of attention. He seems to be irritated, disturbing others, and restless most of the time. What should be the drug to be given? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methylphenidate

 

The boy's symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and restlessness are indicative of Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Methylphenidate is the first-line treatment for ADHD and is FDA-approved for use in children aged six years and older. It is a stimulant medication that has been found to be more effective in managing ADHD symptoms compared to non-stimulants.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atomoxetine: A non-stimulant medication also used to treat ADHD but generally considered when stimulants are not effective or cause intolerable side effects.

 

Option C. Guanfacine: Another non-stimulant medication for ADHD, typically used as an adjunctive treatment or when stimulants are not suitable.

 

Option D. Clozapine: An antipsychotic medication used primarily for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and not indicated for ADHD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Methylphenidate is the drug of choice for managing ADHD in children six years and older due to its effectiveness in reducing symptoms of inattention and hyperactivity.

questions.text: Identify the condition for which Dohlman’s procedure is used: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Zenker's diverticulum

 

Dohlman's procedure is a surgical technique primarily used to treat Zenker's diverticulum. Zenker's diverticulum is a pouch that forms at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx, causing swallowing difficulties, regurgitation, and aspiration. Dohlman's procedure involves endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to alleviate the obstruction and diverticulum formation. This method is favored for its minimal invasiveness and effectiveness in managing the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum is treated with a diverticulectomy, which involves the surgical removal of the diverticulum. This congenital anomaly of the small intestine often presents with bleeding, inflammation, or obstruction.

 

Option C. Bochdalek hernia: Bochdalek hernia, a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, is typically treated with laparotomy or laparoscopic surgery and subsequent hernia repair. This condition involves abdominal organs herniating into the thoracic cavity through a defect in the diaphragm.

 

Option D. Menetrier's disease: Menetrier's disease, a rare disorder characterized by hypertrophic gastric folds and protein-losing gastropathy, does not have a specific surgical procedure for treatment. Management often includes supportive care, protein supplements, and medications such as proton pump inhibitors or cetuximab.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dohlman's procedure is specifically used to treat Zenker's diverticulum by endoscopic division of the cricopharyngeal muscle to relieve symptoms caused by the diverticulum.

questions.text: What is the most common reason for women discontinuing the use of an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD)? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abnormal uterine bleeding

 

Abnormal uterine bleeding is the most common reason for discontinuation of IUCD use. Pain, abnormal uterine bleeding and PID are the principal factors related to IUCD discontinuation (10-15%). The abnormal menstrual bleeding includes excessive menstrual blood loss, prolongation of duration of period, and intermenstrual bleeding. This may cause anemia in users and becomes a significant concern, especially in women who are already anemic.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ectopic pregnancy: While IUCDs are associated with ectopic pregnancy (approximately 30% of pregnancies occurring with an IUCD in situ are ectopic), the overall pregnancy rate with IUCDs is very low (0.1-2 HWY), making this a rare event rather than a common reason for discontinuation.

 

Option B. Uterine rupture: Uterine perforation is a complication of IUCDs with an incidence of about 1 in 1000 insertions. This is an uncommon complication and not among the principal factors for women discontinuing IUCD use.

 

Option D. Risk of subsequent infertility: This is not a common reason for discontinuation. IUCDs actually have "easy return to fertility" as an advantage, and there is no evidence of compromised future fertility with proper IUCD use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Abnormal uterine bleeding is the leading cause of IUCD discontinuation (10-15% of cases), followed by pain and pelvic inflammatory disease.

choices.text: Most common photosensitive material is Silver Bromide
Total thickness of the film is about 0.25 mm

questions.text: All of the following are true about X-Ray Film, Except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Photosensitive material lies in the base

 

Explanation: 

 

X-ray film is made of silver halide (AgBr), which is the photosensitive material. This material is contained in the emulsion layer, not in the base of the film. The base serves as a support structure for the emulsion layer containing the photosensitive silver bromide.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Typically made of 4 layers - This option is true. While the exact number of layers isn't explicitly stated, this would be consistent with standard X-ray film construction which typically includes a base, adhesive layer, emulsion layer(s), and protective coating.

 

Option B. Most common photosensitive material is Silver Bromide - This option is true. Silver bromide (AgBr) is the photosensitive material used in X-ray films as mentioned in the description of film composition.

 

Option C. Photosensitive material lies in the base - This option is false. The photosensitive material (silver bromide) is contained in the emulsion layer of the film, not in the base layer. The base serves as the supporting structure for the film.

 

Option D. Total thickness of the film is about 0.25 mm - This option is likely true based on standard X-ray film properties, though the exact measurement isn't explicitly provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-ray film construction consists of multiple layers with the photosensitive silver halide (AgBr) contained in the emulsion layer, not in the base layer which primarily provides structural support for the film.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with fatigue and tiredness. He had low Hb and reticulocyte count. BM reveals a decrease in erythroid precursors. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pure red cell aplasia

 

Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a selective decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to a significant reduction in red blood cells (RBCs), while white blood cells (WBCs) and platelets remain unaffected. This condition differs from aplastic anemia, where all three cell lines (RBCs, WBCs, and platelets) are decreased.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: This condition typically presents with low Hb but is associated with microcytic, hypochromic RBCs due to insufficient iron for hemoglobin synthesis. It does not specifically cause a decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow.

 

Option B. Megaloblastic anemia: This type of anemia results from defective DNA synthesis, often due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency, leading to the presence of megaloblasts (abnormally large erythroid precursors) in the bone marrow, rather than a reduction in their number.

 

Option C. Pernicious anemia: A form of megaloblastic anemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency due to intrinsic factor deficiency. Similar to megaloblastic anemia, it is characterized by ineffective erythropoiesis with megaloblastic changes in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pure red cell aplasia is characterized by a specific decrease in erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, leading to anemia with normal WBC and platelet counts.

choices.text: Stop warfarin and start LMWH.
Stop warfarin and start heparin.
Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy 4mg/ day. What is the appropriate next step in management. (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stop warfarin and start LMWH.

 

Explanation:

 

Stop warfarin and start LMWH: Warfarin is teratogenic and has a significant risk of causing warfarin embryopathy, particularly in doses greater than 5mg per day. In pregnancy, it is recommended to change warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) in the first trimester, especially if the warfarin dose exceeds 5 mg/day. After 13 weeks, it can be switched back to warfarin until delivery. Near delivery, warfarin should again be replaced by LMWH or UFH to manage the risk of bleeding complications during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stop warfarin and start heparin: This option is partially correct as it aligns with the practice of switching from warfarin to a safer anticoagulant near delivery. However, the preferred anticoagulant in this situation is LMWH due to its predictable pharmacokinetics and ease of administration.

 

Option C. Continue warfarin: This is incorrect because continuing warfarin at 36 weeks of gestation poses significant risks of fetal hemorrhage and warfarin embryopathy. It is essential to switch to a safer anticoagulant like LMWH or UFH close to delivery.

 

Option D. Stop warfarin, start LMWH and aspirin: While this option includes stopping warfarin and starting LMWH, which is correct, the addition of aspirin is only indicated in women who are at a very high risk of thrombosis. The general recommendation does not include aspirin unless there is a specific high-risk indication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Warfarin should be replaced by low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) or unfractionated heparin (UFH) near delivery to manage the risks associated with its teratogenic effects and potential complications during delivery.

 

Ref: Page no 2404, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the implant shown in the image used for treatment of proximal femoral fracture. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dynamic hip screw

 

The image shows an implant used for the treatment of proximal femoral fractures, specifically intertrochanteric fractures. The implant depicted is a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), which is composed of two main components: a large screw (commonly referred to as a Richard screw) and a plate with a barrel. The screw slides within the barrel as the bone heals, allowing controlled movement and promoting bone union.

 

The DHS has been the gold standard for treating intertrochanteric fractures, especially extracapsular femoral neck fractures. It works by providing stability while allowing dynamic compression at the fracture site, which helps in bone healing. However, with advancements in medical technology, cephalomedullary nails (such as the proximal femoral nail) have largely replaced the DHS for such fractures in recent times.

 

Two types of proximal femoral fractures:

 

  1. Fracture of the neck of femur (intra-capsular):
    • Less than 65 years of age: Perform closed reduction (do not open) and fix with cannulated cancellous screw fixation (fixation with screws).
    • More than or equal to 65 years of age: Perform hemiarthroplasty (replace half the joint).
    • Any age with joint damage: Perform total hip replacement (for hip joint damage).
    • Neck of femur fracture is also referred to as the unsolved fracture.
  2. Intertrochanteric fractures:
    • Treatment options include the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral fracture treatment.
    • Modern treatment involves placing nails:
      • Cephalomedullary or proximal femoral nail: A nail is placed inside the femur, with a screw into the head of the femur.
    • Fractures lower down: Treated with interlock nailing.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dynamic condylar plate: The dynamic condylar plate is primarily used for distal femoral fractures, not proximal femoral fractures like intertrochanteric fractures. It does not have the screw-barrel mechanism that is specific to the dynamic hip screw.

 

Option C. Dynamic trochanteric plate: While similar-sounding, the dynamic trochanteric plate is not commonly used for intertrochanteric fractures. The DHS is more specifically designed for dynamic compression in such cases.

 

Option D. Limited contact condylar plate: This plate is generally used for fractures that require minimal disturbance of the periosteum, but it is not typically used for intertrochanteric fractures, which require dynamic fixation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is a two-part implant, featuring a screw and a plate, and is used to treat intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur.

questions.text: A total of 2000 patients were assessed for HIV. 200 were diagnosed positive. A new ELISA screening test was tested on the same group. It showed 260 as positive, out of which only 130 had the disease. What is the specificity of the test? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 93%

 

To calculate specificity

 

  • Total patients = 2000
  • True disease positive = 200
  • True disease negative = 1800
  • ELISA positive = 260 (130 true positive + 130 false positive)
  • ELISA negative = 1740 (70 false negative + 1670 true negative)

 

 

Specificity = True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Positives) × 100 = 1670/1800 × 100 = 93%

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Specificity is the ability of a test to correctly identify those without the disease (true negatives) and is calculated as True Negatives/(True Negatives + False Positives) × 100.

questions.text: A child had a fall at home and was treated with an elbow cast. After the removal of the cast, the child developed the deformity as shown. Which fracture most likely caused this deformity? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar humerus fracture

 

The image shows a child with a deformity known as cubitus varus, which is a complication of supracondylar humerus fractures. This deformity occurs when the distal part of the arm deviates medially, leading to a "gunstock" appearance of the arm. Cubitus varus is a known consequence of a malunited supracondylar humerus fracture, where the carrying angle of the elbow is reduced.

 

Supracondylar fractures are common in children, especially after a fall on an outstretched hand, and improper alignment during healing can lead to this deformity. The deformity is mostly a cosmetic issue but is directly associated with this type of fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial head fracture: Radial head fractures typically present with pain during rotation of the forearm and do not commonly cause cubitus varus or valgus deformities. The main issue with radial head fractures is decreased range of motion, particularly pronation and supination, rather than a visible deformity like in this case.

 

Option B. Lateral condyle humerus fracture: A lateral condyle fracture can lead to cubitus valgus, where the distal part of the arm deviates laterally, increasing the carrying angle. This is the opposite deformity to cubitus varus, which we see here. Non-union of lateral condyle fractures is the common cause of cubitus valgus, not cubitus varus.

 

Option C. Mid-shaft humerus fracture: A mid-shaft humerus fracture does not typically result in deformities like cubitus varus. While this fracture can result in functional issues, especially related to nerve injury (such as radial nerve palsy), it does not lead to elbow deformities unless complicated by additional elbow injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cubitus varus, a "gunstock" deformity, is a classic complication of malunited supracondylar humerus fractures in children, where the carrying angle is reduced, causing medial deviation of the arm.

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.text:
A 8-year-old child weighing 26 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines? (NEET PG 2023)

 

RBS → 550

рН → 7.01

Na+ → 158

Urine glucose → 3+

Urine Ketone → +ve
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Manage ABC, NS 10-20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

 

The given clinical scenario points to diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis

 

According to the ISPAD guidelines shown below, first the patient has to be classified for shock/Moderate dehydration/minimal dehydration. In this given scenario, child is in shock, so, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC) and fluid replacement along with an IV bolus of 20 mL/kg 0.9% Normal saline, followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.05 - 0.1 U/kg/hr, 1 hour after starting fluid replacement therapy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr.: First we will give fluids and then after one hour we will give insulin

 

Option C. Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr: The fluid volume of 10 mL/kg is insufficient for severe dehydration and shock. The correct volume is 20 mL/kg.

 

Option D. Manage ABC, NS 30 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour: This option provides an insufficient fluid volume and delays insulin administration, which is not recommended in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) in children, the initial treatment includes managing ABC, administering 20 mL/kg of 0.9% normal saline, and starting an insulin infusion at 0.1 U/kg/hr.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

 

AQl categories and the range are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Mrs. Patel is a 45-year-old woman who has recently been diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Her doctor informs her that the cancer is hormone-dependent. The doctor recommends a treatment plan that includes surgery, radiation therapy, and hormone therapy. What is the drug used for estrogen dependent breast cancer? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tamoxifen

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) used to treat hormone receptor-positive breast cancers, particularly in premenopausal women. It is effective for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer, which is hormone-dependent. Tamoxifen works by blocking the effects of estrogen in the breast tissue, thereby preventing cancer cells from growing and spreading.

  • Mechanism of Action: Tamoxifen competes with estrogen for binding to estrogen receptors in breast tissue. By blocking estrogen's effects, it inhibits the growth and proliferation of estrogen-dependent cancer cells.
  • Administration: Tamoxifen is taken orally, usually once a day for five years.
  • Side Effects: Common side effects include hot flashes, mood changes, vaginal dryness, and an increased risk of blood clots (DVT).

 

Uses of Tamoxifen:

  • Primary Prophylaxis: Used for the primary prophylaxis of breast cancer in high-risk women.
  • Risk Reduction: Reduces the risk of carcinoma in the contralateral breast.
  • Recurrence Prevention: Lowers the risk of recurrence of carcinoma in both ipsilateral and contralateral breasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Estrogen: Estrogen is not used as a treatment for estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer because it would promote cancer cell growth. In fact, therapies aim to reduce or block estrogen to prevent cancer progression.

 

Option B. Clomiphene citrate: Clomiphene citrate is a medication used to induce ovulation in women with fertility issues. It is not used in the treatment of breast cancer.

 

Option D. Adriamycin (Doxorubicin): Adriamycin is a chemotherapy drug used to treat various types of cancer, including breast cancer. It works by interfering with the DNA in cancer cells, preventing them from dividing and growing. While effective in some cancer treatments, it is not specifically used for hormone therapy in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen is the drug used for treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer by blocking the effects of estrogen on breast tissue, thereby preventing the growth and spread of hormone-dependent cancer cells.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with 15 days of cough. On examination, cervical lymphadenopathy was noted and the lymph node biopsy showed the following features. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculosis

 

The histopathological picture of the caseating granuloma, eosinophilic necrotic debris known as caseation, bordered by collections of epithelioid cells, Langhan giant cells (horse shoe shape), and lymphocytes, as well as the clinical history, indicate tuberculosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES: Tuberculosis presents with chronic cough, fever, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leprosy: Skin lesions and nerve involvement with loss of sensation.

 

Option C. Sarcoidosis: Giant cells with cytoplasmic inclusions, non-caseating granuloma with fibroblastic proliferation at the periphery.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Thickened capsule/ hyperplasia of capsule accompanied by fibrosis, perivascular inflammation, and infiltration of chronic inflammatory cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculosis is characterized by caseating granulomas with eosinophilic necrotic debris, surrounded by epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes. This histopathological pattern, along with the clinical presentation of chronic cough and cervical lymphadenopathy, is indicative of tuberculosis.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient is diagnosed with gouty arthritis. Mark the correct biochemical changes which will be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased urate and lactate levels

 

This patient with chronic alcoholism and gouty arthritis will most likely have elevated levels of lactate and urate.

 

The oxidation of ethanol to acetate by alcohol dehydrogenase is accompanied by the reduction of NAD+ to NADH. This results in a high concentration of NADH, leading to an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio (Hence ruled out Option A).

 

 

Due to this, the following metabolic reactions which require NAD+ are inhibited:

  1. Glycolysis
  2. Citric acid cycle (ketogenesis favoured)
  3. Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  4. Fatty acid oxidation

 

This decreased fatty acid oxidation leads to increased esterification and production of triacylglycerol, which causes fatty liver.

In addition to this, there is an increase in two reactions:

  • Pyruvate to lactate
  • Oxaloacetate to malate

 

Increased lactate leads to hyper-lactic-acidemia, which leads to increased renal reabsorption of urate and decreased excretion of uric acid. This results in aggravation of gout.

 

Alcoholics are deficient in thiamine which inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase and these all leads to lactic acidosis.

 

A decrease in pyruvate and oxaloacetate levels, which are substrates for gluconeogenesis, leads to a decrease in blood glucose levels, causing symptoms of agitation, impaired judgement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Decreased NADH/NAD+ ratio: This is incorrect as the NADH/NAD+ ratio is actually increased due to the metabolism of ethanol.

 

Option B: Increased urea and urate levels are not specifically associated with alcoholism and gouty arthritis. But urate levels may be increased due to gout, urea levels are not directly related to the condition.

 

Option D: Increased levels of alkaline phosphatase can be seen in alcohol-induced hepatitis due to intrahepatic cholestasis but is not directly related to gouty arthritis in a chronic alcoholic patient. Therefore, this option is less relevant compared to increased rate and lactate levels.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the article in the constitution that is not related to pediatrics? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 42

 

Article 42 says that the state shall make provision for securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief. It is not directly related to pediatrics but rather focuses on the welfare of workers and maternity benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Articles in constitution related to children:

 

Option A. Article 21 A: Right to free and compulsory elementary education in the 6 -14-year age group.

 

Option B. Article 24: Right to be protected from any hazardous employment till 14 years of age.

 

Option C. Article 39 E: Right to be protected from being abused.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Article 42 is not related to pediatrics, as it focuses on working conditions and maternity relief, unlike Articles 21A, 24, and 39E, which are specifically aimed at the rights and protection of children.

questions.text: The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chorioretinitis

 

  • The most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis is chorioretinitis.
  • Congenital toxoplasmosis is an infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii that occurs when a pregnant woman becomes infected and passes the infection on to her developing fetus. The severity of the infection can vary depending on the timing of the infection during pregnancy and the degree of immune response mounted by the fetus.
  • It is acquired perorally from ingesting food that contains oocysts; transplacentally, during vaginal delivery; or rarely, parenterally.
  • Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, occurring in up to 80% of affected infants. It is a type of eye inflammation that affects the retina and can lead to vision impairment or blindness if left untreated.
  • Other common manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus (accumulation of fluid in the brain), hepatosplenomegaly (enlargement of the liver and spleen), and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count), but these are less common than chorioretinitis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydrocephalus: Accumulation of fluid in the brain can occur in congenital toxoplasmosis but is less common than chorioretinitis.

 

Option C. Hepatosplenomegaly: Enlargement of the liver and spleen is another possible manifestation but not as common as chorioretinitis.

 

Option D. Thrombocytopenia: Low platelet count can occur but is less common compared to chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chorioretinitis is the most common manifestation of congenital toxoplasmosis, affecting up to 80% of infected infants and potentially leading to vision impairment or blindness.

questions.text: Cushing's ulcers are seen in? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Head injury

 

Cushing's ulcers are specifically associated with head injuries or conditions that lead to increased intracranial pressure (ICP). The mechanism involves vagal nerve stimulation due to the increased ICP, which in turn causes an overproduction of gastric acid leading to the development of ulcers. This is distinct from other types of stress-related gastric ulcers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burns: This type of ulcer is known as Curling's ulcer, which occurs in response to severe burns and is related to the physiological stress and possible hypovolemia resulting from the burn injury, not the brain injury-related mechanism of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Option B. Stress: While stress can indeed lead to gastric ulcers, the specific term "Cushing's ulcers" is not used in this context. General stress-related ulcers do not typically involve the mechanism of vagal stimulation due to increased ICP.

 

Option D. Cell necrosis: This is a general process that can occur in many pathological conditions but does not specifically relate to the formation of Cushing's ulcers.

 

Educational Objective:


Cushing's ulcers are a specific type of peptic ulcer that occurs due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from head injuries. Recognizing this condition is important for managing patients with significant neurological trauma to prevent and treat these potentially serious gastrointestinal complications.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with symptoms of acute bacterial prostatitis, including fever, chills, dysuria, and perineal pain. A urine sample is taken, and a culture is performed, which reveals the presence of a common organism associated with acute bacterial prostatitis. Identify the organism?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. E. coli

 

Escherichia coli, commonly known as E. coli, is a gram-negative bacillus and is part of the normal flora of the gastrointestinal tract. E. coli is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the vast majority of cases. It's also a very common cause of urinary tract infections in general.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterococcus: Enterococcus species are gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal gut flora. They are an infrequent cause of acute bacterial prostatitis.

 

Option B. Proteus: Proteus species are gram-negative bacilli. They can cause a variety of infections, including urinary tract infections and, less commonly, prostatitis. A characteristic of Proteus infections is the production of urease, which splits urea into ammonia and leads to an alkaline urine that can cause struvite stone formation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus Agalactiae: Also known as Group B Streptococcus (GBS), Streptococcus agalactiae is a gram-positive coccus. While it's a leading cause of neonatal infections, it's an infrequent cause of urinary tract infections in adults and an even rarer cause of prostatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of acute bacterial prostatitis, accounting for the majority of cases and is frequently found in urinary tract infections.

questions.text: Best indicator for chronic malnutrition in children is: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Height for age

 

Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition in children. When height for age is low, it indicates stunting, which develops over a long period due to chronic nutritional deficiency. This is because:

 

  • Height takes a longer time to be affected by nutritional deficiency
  • Once affected, height also takes longer to recover
  • Therefore, low height for age (stunting) reflects long-term or chronic nutritional deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight for age:

 

  • Indicates underweight status
  • Reflects acute on chronic malnutrition
  • Can change relatively quickly with nutritional status

 

Option B. Weight for height:

 

  • Indicates wasting
  • Reflects acute malnutrition
  • Changes rapidly with current nutritional status

 

Option D. Head circumference:

 

  • Not a primary indicator for malnutrition
  • More relevant for neurological development assessment
  • Does not specifically reflect nutritional status

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Height for age is the best indicator of chronic malnutrition in children, with low values indicating stunting, while weight for height indicates acute malnutrition (wasting) and weight for age indicates acute on chronic malnutrition (underweight).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman came to the OPD with a diagnosis of advanced cervical cancer. She has a 14-year-old daughter. What advice would you give for her daughter? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Advise HPV vaccine

 

The patient's 14-year-old daughter should be advised to take the HPV vaccine.

 

Screening CA cervix begins at the age of 25 years.

 

HPV vaccine

 

  • Contains recombinant VLP (L1 synthetic capsid protein)
  • Types –
    • Cervarix: Bivalent (16,18)
    • Gardasil: Quadrivalent (6,11,16,18)
    • Gardasil 9: Nonavalent (6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58)
    • Dosing as per IAP:
      • Girls 9 to 14 years: 2 doses
      • > 15 years: 3 doses

 

On June 1, 2023 there will be the launch of Indian indigenous vaccine called Cervavac , quadrivalent vaccine produce by Serum Institute of India (6, 11, 16, 18).

 

WHO’s Safe Advisory Group (SAGE) in 2021 advised regarding updating dose schedules for HPV as follows:

 

  • One or two-dose schedule for the primary target of girls aged 9-14
  • One or two-dose schedule for young women aged 15-20
  • Two doses with a 6-month interval for women older than 21

 

Immunocompromised individuals, including those with HIV, should receive three doses if feasible, and if not at least two doses. There is limited evidence regarding the efficacy of a single dose in this group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Screen for BRCA mutation: BRCA mutation causes breast cancer, ovarian cancer, endometrial cancer

 

Option C. Screen for PTEN mutation: PTEN mutation (chromosome 10) causes Cowden syndrome, has 20-30% risk of developing endometrial cancer.

 

Option D. Perform cervical biopsy: Cervical biopsy is not indicated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HPV vaccine is essential for preventing cervical cancer and should be administered to girls aged 9 to 14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.

questions.text: Arrange the stages of wound healing in the correct sequence: (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, remodeling 

 

Wound healing is a complex and dynamic process involving a sequence of interrelated phases. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The correct sequence of wound healing stages is hemostasis, inflammation, proliferation, and remodeling, reflecting the orderly process of wound repair from clot formation to tissue regeneration and maturation.

questions.text: What condition describes the prolapse of the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cystocele

 

Cystocele specifically refers to the laxity and descent of the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall. The bladder base is closely related to this area, resulting in herniation of the bladder through the lax anterior wall. This represents a specific type of anterior wall prolapse where the bladder protrudes through the weakened vaginal tissues, creating a bulge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethrocele: This refers to laxity of the lower-third of the anterior vaginal wall, where the urethra herniates through the defect. Urethrocele often appears with cystocele, forming a cystourethrocele.

 

Option C. Rectocele: This is a posterior vaginal wall defect, not anterior. It involves laxity of the middle-third of the posterior vaginal wall and the adjacent rectovaginal septum, resulting in herniation of the rectum through the lax area.

 

Option D. Enterocele: This involves the upper-third of the posterior vaginal wall, not the anterior wall. It represents herniation of the pouch of Douglas, which may contain omentum or even loops of small bowel.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cystocele specifically involves the upper two-thirds of the anterior vaginal wall with bladder herniation, while other types of prolapse affect different anatomical compartments of the vagina.

questions.text: Exclusive ketogenic amino acids include? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leucine

 

Explanation:

 

Leucine is an exclusively ketogenic amino acid, meaning its carbon skeleton is converted solely to ketone body synthesis. Leucine is categorized under Ketogenic while the other amino acids mentioned have different metabolic fates.

 

The catabolism of leucine proceeds through β-methylcrotonyl-CoA and ultimately forms acetoacetate and acetyl-CoA, without producing any glucose precursors. This exclusive ketogenic nature makes leucine unique among the listed options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Isoleucine: Isoleucine is both glucogenic and ketogenic, not exclusively ketogenic. Its carbon skeleton is partially converted to succinyl-CoA (which can enter gluconeogenesis) and partially to acetyl-CoA. Isoleucine is classified under both Glucogenic and Ketogenic.

 

Option C. Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is also both glucogenic and ketogenic. Its catabolism involves conversion to tyrosine, whose subsequent breakdown yields both fumarate (glucogenic) and acetoacetate (ketogenic). It is classified under both Glucogenic and Ketogenic.

 

Option D. Tyrosine: Like phenylalanine, tyrosine is both glucogenic and ketogenic. Its breakdown pathway produces fumarate (glucogenic) and acetoacetate (ketogenic). Tyrosine is classified under both Glucogenic and Ketogenic.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Leucine is the only exclusively ketogenic amino acid among the provided options, as its catabolism yields only acetoacetate and acetyl-CoA, which can be used for ketogenesis but not for gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 21 hydroxylase deficiency

 

The clinical scenario describes a 3-year-old girl with ambiguous genitalia, specifically an enlarged clitoris, and a karyotype of 46XX. This presentation is indicative of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH), which is most commonly caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

 

21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common form of CAH and accounts for more than 95% of cases. This enzyme deficiency leads to impaired cortisol production, which results in an increased production of androgens. The excess androgens cause virilization, leading to ambiguous genitalia in genotypically female infants.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Ambiguous genitalia: This includes an enlarged clitoris, which is often a sign of virilization due to increased androgens.
  • Karyotype 46XX: Confirms the genetic female status.
  • Increased serum androgens: Result from the enzyme deficiency and lead to masculinization of the external genitalia.

 

Clinical scenario: Ambiguous genitalia in a newborn female

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 11 hydroxylase deficiency: This can also lead to CAH but is less common and typically presents with hypertension due to the accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone, which has mineralocorticoid activity.
